proposals.reasoning: There’s broad consensus around Grace + Frank + Iris as a steady, low-drama starting team. Grace is widely trusted as an anchor, Frank and Iris both have consistent, transparent styles, and keeping several of the louder voices (including myself) off Mission 1 gives us cleaner outside perspectives on the result. With no prior info, this lineup maximizes early informational value while minimizing the chance that evil is heavily clustered or completely hidden among the most vocal players.

votes.comment: Broad consensus and a reasonable low-drama baseline; no info yet to justify rocking the boat on Mission 1.
Solid, broadly agreed-on starter with no known red flags; fine for early info even if it’s not guaranteed clean.
Solid, broadly supported low-drama opener with no red flags; good for early info while strong talkers stay outside to interpret.
Team has an evil member while looking consensus-based and low-risk, giving us early influence on the outcome without raising suspicion.
This is a broadly agreed, info-rich starter team and I’d like to see how it resolves, especially with several strong talkers off the mission.
I’m on the team and it matches the broad consensus for a solid, low-drama starter, so I’m fine using this to get early info.
Standard info-gathering Mission 1 team, I’m on it and there’s broad consensus; rejecting now gives us no extra info.
Standard low-drama M1; good info value and keeps several loud players outside for clearer reads later.
Solid, consensus-based low-drama opener; I’m fine taking the info from a Grace+Frank+me team on Quest 1.

discussion.content: With no info yet, I’d like to start with people who are usually steady and transparent, so I’m inclined toward including someone like Diana or Grace on the first team. I’d also rather avoid clustering the loudest voices together early so we don’t give evil an easy place to hide.

I like starting with Grace plus one of the more consistently level-headed folks like Frank or Iris, just so we’ve got a solid baseline. I’d rather not auto-include Diana right away only because she tends to fly under the radar, and I don’t want our first read to be on a super quiet slot.

I like anchoring Mission 1 with Grace plus one of Frank/Iris for that steady baseline Bob mentioned, and I’d rather stay off the first team so we get more independent data points instead of stacking all the vocal players together.
I’m fine staying off Mission 1; I’d lean toward something like Grace + Iris + Alice as a pretty balanced, low-drama starting point so we at least get a clean-ish data point to work from.

I’m good with keeping this first team pretty middle-of-the-road: Grace + Frank + Iris feels like a reasonable balance of steady playstyles without overloading it with the loudest voices. I’d rather stay off Mission 1 so we get a clearer read from the outside.

I’m fine taking a spot on Mission 1 alongside Grace, and I’d like at least one quieter-but-consistent voice like Iris rather than stacking too many strong talkers together, so something like Grace + Frank + Iris works for me.

I’m happy to be on Mission 1, and given what everyone’s said so far, Grace + Frank + Iris seems like a solid, low-risk starting team to get some early info without stacking all the table captains together.

Grace + Frank + Iris is a pretty reasonable Mission 1 for info, and I like keeping a couple of the louder voices (me, Charlie, Bob) off so we have clearer outside perspectives on the result. I’d support that team unless someone has a strong objection.

Grace + Frank + me seems like a fine low-drama starter, and I like keeping more of the strong talkers (and my early Merlin-lean candidates) on the bench so we get outside perspectives on the result. I’m happy to go on that team unless someone has a concrete reason to swap a slot.

proposals.reasoning: I want a mostly new team while still using the info from Mission 1. This keeps exactly one of {Grace, Frank, Iris} to avoid wasting that data, and adds two players who weren’t on the first mission (Bob and Charlie) plus Alice, who led the previous team. That matches the earlier table consensus for a ‘mostly new plus one from the first team’ approach, avoids clustering too many of the M1 suspects together again, and should give us a clearer read on where the first fail came from based on how this mission turns out.

votes.comment: I’d rather bench all of {Grace, Frank, Iris} once, as several suggested, to get a cleaner read from a team like Alice + Charlie + Diana + Henry/Bob instead of gambling on exactly one from the suspect trio again.
Keeps both Diana and Eve off while only retaining one from the M1 group, which fits the ‘mostly new plus one’ plan and should give a cleaner read than options that include Diana.

I’d rather bench all of {Grace, Frank, Iris} this round after a failed M1; including Frank keeps a likely suspect on a crucial info-gathering team when we can instead run a fully fresh lineup like Alice + Charlie + Diana + Henry/Bob for a cleaner read and higher success odds.
It follows the ‘mostly new plus one from {Grace, Frank, Iris}’ plan I supported earlier, and I was already leaning slightly toward including Frank from that group for this mission.
Fits the mostly-new-plus-one-from-{Grace,Frank,Iris} plan I supported earlier, and keeping exactly one M1 member gives us good info from the result without overstacking known suspects.
I’m on the team and can choose to keep it clean; a mostly new group gives good info while preserving evil’s lead.

I know I’m good, so the Mission 1 fail came from {Frank, Iris}. Including Frank here keeps a likely evil on the team when we could instead bench both suspects and run an all-new group for a cleaner read.
I wanted all of {Grace, Frank, Iris} benched for a clean read; this keeps Frank and omits both Diana and me, so it’s a higher-risk mix than necessary while we’re already down 0–1.

I wanted all of {Grace, Frank, Iris} benched this round; this keeps Frank from the suspect trio on, which feels unnecessary when we could run a fully fresh team like Alice+Bob+Charlie+Diana/Henry instead.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 already guarantees at least one evil among {Grace, Frank, Iris}, and we can’t afford another early fail. The safest, highest-confidence approach is to bench all three of them this round and run a fully new team around the consensus core. Alice and I (Charlie) were widely requested for fresh info, Diana was part of multiple suggested lineups and has read naturally good so far, and Henry is the cleanest fourth based on his push to bench the suspicious trio rather than subtly protect any of them. This gives us a team completely outside the M1 pool, maximizes the chance of a success, and provides a clear data point on four players who were not on the failed mission.

votes.comment: Benches all three from the failed M1 team and tests four fresh players, maximizing chance of success and giving clean info.

I don’t love completely throwing out the M1 group; I’d rather see a lineup that includes at least one of {Grace, Frank, Iris} plus someone like Bob for better comparative info instead of a fully fresh four.
Benches the entire suspicious M1 trio and uses four players with no direct taint from the failed mission; best chance for a clean success and strong new info.
Matches the bench-{Grace,Frank,Iris} plan and the mostly new team I already supported including myself.
I don’t like completely benching all of {Grace, Frank, Iris}; I’d rather keep exactly one of them on for clearer info instead of creating a potentially too-clean block of four new players.
This is the cleanest, fully new team outside the M1 pool; we need a low‑risk info-gathering mission here.

Benching all of {Grace, Frank, Iris} after a fail is the safest structure; a fully new four gives us a high-chance success and a clean info point, and there’s no concrete reason yet to distrust any of Alice/Charlie/Diana/Henry over alternatives.
This matches the safest structure I argued for: bench all of {Grace, Frank, Iris} and test a fully new quartet, maximizing success odds and giving clear info if it fails.
Team fully outside the M1 pool and matches my stated preference to bench {Grace, Frank, Iris}, so this is our safest high‑info option right now.

discussion.content: We’ve got exactly one evil in {Grace, Frank, Iris}, so for this round I’d like to keep at most one of them on the team and fill the rest with people outside that set—ideally including myself so we get some fresh info.

I like Alice’s idea of mostly going outside {Grace, Frank, Iris}, but I’d still keep at least one of them so we’re not throwing away all that info—something like Alice + one of {Grace/Frank/Iris} + two from {Charlie, Henry} feels like a reasonable starting point.
I’m fine assuming exactly one evil in {Grace, Frank, Iris}, so for this one I’d like a mostly “new” team like Alice + Bob + me, plus just one of {Grace, Frank, Iris}.

I like the “mostly new” approach too, something like Alice + Charlie + me plus exactly one of {Grace, Frank, Iris}, and right now I’m leaning slightly toward Frank from that group since his reaction to the fail felt the most natural to me.

I’m on board with the “mostly new” idea, and from the M1 reactions I’d slightly prefer Frank over Grace/Iris, so something like Alice + Charlie + Diana + Frank feels like a solid info-gathering team to me.

I’m okay with the “mostly new plus one from {Grace, Frank, Iris}” idea, but I don’t want us to lock in “exactly one evil” there as fact yet. If we go Alice + Charlie + Diana, I’m fine being the fourth, though I’d also be okay with testing Grace instead of me if people are worried about how clean that looks for me later.

I’m really not a fan of everyone treating “exactly one evil in {me, Frank, Iris}” as locked-in truth, so I’d actually prefer we run something like Alice + Charlie + Diana + Bob this round and leave all three of us off for a cleaner read.

I’d rather we treat {Grace, Frank, Iris} as “at least one evil, maybe more” and just bench all three this time; something like Alice + Charlie + Diana + me feels like the cleanest way to get a high‑confidence read on Mission 2.

I don’t think we should assume it’s exactly one evil in {Grace, Frank, me}, so I’d rather bench all three this round and go with something like Alice + Charlie + Diana + Henry/Bob. Between those, I slightly prefer including Bob for the extra new info.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2 is our only clean data point so far and this exact team (Alice/Charlie/Diana/Henry) just produced a success with no fails. With the score at 1–1, our priority should be maximizing the chance of banking this mission rather than reshuffling too much. Re-running the proven Mission 2 lineup keeps the strongest available core intact and defers any rotation/testing of the Mission 1 pool (Grace/Frank/Iris) to a later mission when we’ll have more information to interpret an additional result.

votes.comment: Reusing the only fully clean team we have (M2) is safest at 1–1; best odds to bank this mission before experimenting with the M1 pool.
I still prefer keeping Alice/Charlie/Henry and rotating the fourth slot to start isolating the M1 fail, rather than locking Diana back in automatically.
Same lineup as the only clean mission we have; with the score tied, this maximizes our odds of a success while keeping the untested Mission 1 pool benched.
I’m on the team and can leverage the trust from Mission 2’s success while pushing this critical midgame mission toward a bad outcome for good.
My evil teammate Diana is on the team, so this gives us a strong chance to sabotage while everyone thinks this core is clean.
This reuses the only proven-success team so far and keeps the suspicious Mission 1 pool off the board for now.
Reusing the only clean team (M2) at 1–1 maximizes our chance to bank this mission; testing the M1 pool can wait until we have this result.
Reusing the only clean team we have (Mission 2) at 1–1 maximizes our chance to bank this mission; if there is an evil here, we’re no worse off than by reshuffling now.
Reusing the only clean team (M2) at 1–1 maximizes pass odds; Bob vs Diana signals make this lineup more likely to contain real Merlin than evil coordination.

discussion.content: I’m most comfortable re-using a core from Mission 2—Alice/Charlie/Diana/Henry felt clean—then maybe adding just one of Grace/Frank/Iris at a time so we can start narrowing down where that first fail came from.

I like keeping Alice/Charlie/Henry from Mission 2, but I’d rather rotate the fourth slot and test one of Grace/Frank/Iris than lock Diana back in automatically. That way we both preserve a mostly proven core and start isolating where Mission 1’s fail came from.

Given M2 came back clean, I’m happiest anchoring around Alice/Henry/me again and then testing *one* of {Grace, Frank, Iris} rather than reshuffling Diana out immediately—we should keep as much of the proven core as possible while probing where that M1 fail came from.

I’m inclined to just rerun the full Mission 2 team of Alice/Charlie/me/Henry here—one clean result isn’t proof, but it’s our best data so far—and then we can start rotating a single slot off that core next round to pinpoint the Mission 1 fail.

I’m fine with rerunning the full Mission 2 team (Alice/Charlie/Diana/Henry) here, and if we *do* start rotating a slot, I’d rather test Grace or Iris first since Mission 1 already points to that pool.
Given Mission 2 came back clean, I’d stick with Alice/Charlie/Diana/Henry here and treat Grace/Iris/me as the pool we rotate into later to sort out where that first fail actually came from.

Given M2 was clean, I’d stick with Alice/Charlie/Diana/Henry for this one and leave the Mission 1 pool (me/Frank/Iris) on the bench until we’ve locked in a stronger core. That gives us the best odds of a pass while we sort out where that first fail came from.

Given the score’s 1–1 and M2 is our only clean data, I’d lock in the full Alice/Charlie/Diana/me core again here and treat Bob’s “rotate the 4th” idea as something we do *after* we (hopefully) bank this mission.
Given the 1–1 score and M2 as our only clean data, I’d rerun Alice/Charlie/Diana/Henry here and keep the Grace/Frank/Iris pool benched until we have another result to work with.

proposals.reasoning: This lineup follows the strongest emerging consensus: build around an Alice/Bob/Eve core and completely bench the contentious M3 block of Charlie, Diana, and Henry. We then add Grace and Iris as the preferred picks from the M1 group, matching proposals like Iris’s suggestion of Alice + Bob + Eve + {Grace/Frank} + Iris while avoiding stacking both of the more controversial M1 names (Frank and Iris) together with Frank. This gives a mostly fresh configuration that separates the M3 suspects entirely, still tests the M1 pool without overloading it with the same exact trio that already failed, and should be broadly acceptable to most players based on the discussion so far.

votes.comment: Best available: fully benches the {Charlie, Diana, Henry} block where we know at least one evil sits, and only lightly taps the M1 suspect pool where it’s still plausible that Frank is the lone evil. This configuration maximizes the chance of a fully good team given the mission history.
This keeps all of M3’s suspects off, which is good, but it introduces a lot of untested risk at once and I don’t like committing to Eve here given the score and lack of clear clears.

Math says there’s at least one evil in {Grace, Frank, Iris} from M1’s fail and at least one evil in {Alice, Diana, Henry} from M3’s fail; this team includes Alice plus both Grace and Iris, so it necessarily has at least two evils.
Only one known evil (Eve) is on the team, giving us a clean shot to win with a single fail while keeping both me and Frank safely off the mission.
I’m on the team and it only includes one known evil, so approving maximizes our chance to get this mission to go and then fail for the evil win.

This matches the structure I advocated—benching the M3 block and using an Alice/Bob/Eve core with Grace/Iris from the M1 pool—so it’s consistent with my earlier reasoning and gives a clean, informative test.

Too many from known-contaminated pools (Alice from M3, Iris from M1) plus two completely untested (Bob, Eve). With evil one fail from victory, I’d rather not stack both a M1 and M3 suspect alongside two unknowns on the same mission.

Too many players from known fail pools: this has Alice from the M3 fail plus two of the three M1 suspects (Grace, Iris). I’d rather limit it to at most one from M1 and one from {Alice, Charlie, Diana} and lean harder on fresh/safer picks.
Too risky for a must-pass mission: still built around suspicious Alice, includes two from the M1 fail pool (Grace, Iris), and adds untested Eve whom Bob explicitly distrusted.

proposals.reasoning: Given M2 was clean but the same Alice/Charlie/Diana/Henry core flipped to a fail on M3, I want to avoid reusing that block heavily and especially keep both Diana and Henry off this mission. There’s also understandable caution around stacking both members of the M1 fail (me and Iris), so I’m only including one of us (me) and benching Iris to minimize that combined risk. Alice is the common anchor most people are comfortable building around, Bob gives us a fresh, generally trusted voice who wasn’t on either fail, and Eve has been widely proposed as part of a new core to test. Grace is a relatively low-drama option who wasn’t on M2 or M3 and only touched the M1 fail via association, so she’s a good candidate to round out a mostly new mix. Overall this team: (1) double-benches the most contentious M3 pairings (Diana/Henry), (2) avoids the full M1 fail duo, and (3) centers the broadly supported Alice/Bob/Eve core while adding two comparatively less-suspected players for a cleaner, info-rich test.

votes.comment: Mission 1 showed at least one of {Grace, Frank, Iris} is evil; this team includes both Grace and Frank, so it’s guaranteed to have at least one evil on it.

I don’t like including Eve here along with both Grace and Frank given the M1 fail and lack of any proven-clean core; I’d rather see a team that leans more heavily on players from the successful M2 plus new blood.

This lineup structurally guarantees at least one evil: we know there’s at least one in {Grace, Frank, Iris}, and this team includes both Grace and Frank. With the score at 1–2, we should avoid any team that is guaranteed to contain an evil and instead cap it at one from each contaminated pool (M1 trio and {Alice, Diana, Henry}).
Two players I distrust (Diana/Henry) are benched and this aligns with the Alice/Bob/Eve core I was pushing for, so I’m fine sending this.
This team includes at least two of my preferred picks and keeps the most contentious M3 pair (Diana/Henry) off, while still looking reasonable to the table.
Puts two players from outside the M2/M3 core on the mission and keeps Diana/Henry benched, while still being a team I can comfortably support.
From my POV evil is in {Frank, Iris} from M1, so I don’t want a team that includes Frank; I’d rather keep both M1 suspects off and use Alice/Bob/Eve plus just one of {Charlie, Henry} instead.

Matches the structure I advocated: bench Diana/Charlie/Henry, avoid the full M1 pair by dropping Iris, and include only one from {Alice,Charlie,Diana}. Risky with both Bob/Eve and Grace/Frank, but this is a reasonable info-rich shot given current beliefs.
Too much risk: it stacks both M1 suspects Grace+Frank together, which several of us wanted to avoid, and doesn’t clearly align with the safer patterns Bob and others were pushing for.

proposals.reasoning: We know Mission 1 (Grace, Frank, Iris) had at least one evil among {Frank, Iris}, so I’m keeping both of them off to avoid that guaranteed-risk pool. Missions 2 and 3 used the identical team {Alice, Charlie, Diana, Henry} with a success then a fail, which means there is at least one evil in that foursome, but not necessarily more. To minimize overlap with that contaminated block, I’m including only Alice and Charlie from it and fully benching Diana and Henry this round. Bob and Eve are completely untested so far and have no direct linkage to any failed mission, making them our cleanest additions. Including myself (Grace) gives a lineup of: Alice (from the strong M2 success core and widely trusted), Bob (fresh, no fail history), Eve (fresh, no fail history), Grace (only linked to M1, where the more likely evil is in {Frank, Iris}), and Charlie (one representative from the M2/M3 group to avoid overstacking that suspect set while still gaining information). This team avoids the known risky M1 pair Frank/Iris, avoids double-stacking Diana and Henry from the M2/M3 block, and centers on the broadly preferred Alice/Bob/Eve core with just one additional suspect from that later mission cluster.

votes.comment: Team still contains one from the M1 fail trio (Grace) and one from the M3 fail block (Charlie), so it’s very plausible there are 2 evils here. I’d rather keep the Alice/Bob/Eve core but swap Grace/Charlie for a safer combo from the remaining pool.

Team still reuses a member from the M2/M3 block and sidelines the entire M1 pair while auto-trusting both new players; I’d rather see a version that benches either Charlie or Eve and pulls in just one of Frank/Iris to better balance the risk pools.

From my POV I know I’m good, so the evil in {Alice, Charlie, Diana, Henry} must be in {Alice, Diana, Henry}, all of whom are benched except Alice. M1’s evil is somewhere in {Grace, Frank, Iris}, but we only take Grace, avoiding the Frank/Iris pair. That leaves at most one likely contaminated slot from each suspicious pool plus two completely fresh players (Bob, Eve), which is a reasonable risk profile given we must secure a success now.

Only one player from the M1 pool and a single member of the M2/M3 block makes this feel like a low-information gamble; if it succeeds we learn almost nothing about where the leaks really are, and I’d rather see a lineup that more cleanly tests one suspect cluster.

I’m on this team and it looks broadly consistent with the table’s preferred Alice/Bob/Eve core while avoiding the heaviest suspicion pools, so it’s likely to pass and gives evil a strong shot to sabotage.
Only one known evil on this team; if a single fail is enough, this gives evil a clear win path.

This avoids the known M1 evil pool {Frank, Iris} and benches both Diana and Henry from the M2/M3 block, which I distrust more than Charlie. Given we must include two from {Alice, Charlie, Diana, Henry} and I read Henry/Diana as shakier, Alice+Charlie with fresh Bob/Eve is the least-bad configuration we’re likely to get before passing leadership to potentially evil players.

This stacks two of my main suspects from the M2/M3 block (Alice and Charlie) plus Grace who was on the M1 fail; I’d rather only take one from {Alice, Charlie, Diana} and lean more on the untainted pool.

Too many overlaps with known risk pools: it stacks M1 (Grace) plus two from the M2/M3 block (Alice, Charlie). With the score at 1–2 we need a cleaner team that benches the whole M2/M3 suspect cluster rather than mixing both fail sources.

proposals.reasoning: From the mission history, Mission 2 (Alice, Charlie, Diana, Henry) was clean and Mission 3 with the same four picked up exactly one FAIL, which implies exactly one of {Alice, Charlie, Diana, Henry} is evil and that evil chose to pass on M2 and fail on M3. Since I know I’m good, that pins exactly one evil in {Alice, Charlie, Diana}. Separately, Mission 1 (Grace, Frank, Iris) had a single FAIL, so there is at least one evil in {Grace, Frank, Iris}. That gives us: 1 evil in {Alice, Charlie, Diana}, ≥1 in {Grace, Frank, Iris}, and the remaining evil(s) in {Bob, Eve, the rest of that M1 set}. To minimize overlap with the proven-contaminated M2/M3 core, I bench all of Alice, Charlie, and Diana. Among the M1 trio, I include Grace and Frank together and bench Iris, on the assumption there is at least one but not necessarily two evils there; taking two of them is a calculated risk, but it lets us avoid the guaranteed 1-in-3 evil from {Alice, Charlie, Diana}. I also add Bob and Eve as fresh, untested players outside both failed cores, plus myself as a known-good to me. Structurally, this team fully excludes the {Alice, Charlie, Diana} pool (where we know there is exactly one evil) and only lightly taps the M1 pool while adding two players (Bob, Eve) who have no direct failure association so far, which I judge to be the best balance of minimizing known risk while still having enough new information potential if something goes wrong.

votes.comment: This stacks two players from the M1 fail pool plus Henry (from the M3 fail pool) while benching me; structurally it leans into known-contaminated groups more than the earlier Alice/Bob/Eve-centric proposals and looks higher-risk for containing multiple evils.

This stacks two from the M1 fail pool plus an untested Eve, giving a plausible double-evil combo; I’d rather see at most one from {Grace, Frank, Iris} and avoid clustering that with fresh, unproven players.

Henry’s logic that there is exactly one evil in {Alice, Charlie, Diana, Henry} is flawed—M2/M3 only prove at least one there, not exactly one. This team still takes Henry from that contaminated pool and includes two members (Grace, Frank) from the known-failed M1 set where at least one evil sits, making it too likely to contain 2 evils.

It fully benches the {Alice, Charlie, Diana} pool that’s guaranteed to contain 1 evil and leans on fresh blood (Bob/Eve) plus a different mix from the M1 trio, which feels like a better structural gamble than reusing the known-contaminated M2/M3 core again.

This cleanly sidelines the entire {Alice, Charlie, Diana} block that’s tied to the M3 fail and mixes only part of the M1 trio with two relatively untested players, which feels like a reasonable way to avoid the most obvious contaminated core while still getting useful info if it fails.
This benches the entire {Alice, Charlie, Diana} pool that keeps causing trouble and mixes in mostly fresh blood; I’m fine taking the calculated risk on two from the M1 group here.

This stacks both a Mission 1 suspect pair (Grace/Frank) and a Mission 3 suspect (Henry); from a good perspective that’s too much known risk on one team when we can build safer by limiting overlap with each failed pool.

This stacks two people from the known-contaminated Mission 1 pool (Grace, Frank) plus two completely untested (Bob, Eve). With at least one evil in {Grace, Frank, Iris}, taking both Grace and Frank together feels too risky when we still haven’t tested alternatives that use only one from that set.

Henry’s reasoning overclaims that there’s exactly one evil in {Alice, Charlie, Diana}, and this team takes the high-risk choice of including both Grace and Frank from the M1 fail pool plus Henry from the M2/M3 pool. That’s too much exposure to known-risk groups when we can field a lineup that benches the whole M2/M3 core and uses at most one M1 player.

proposals.reasoning: I want to avoid stacking the main risk pools from the failed missions while still leveraging info we have. Mission 1’s fail implicates some combination of {Grace, Frank, Iris}, but Grace wasn’t on any failed mission yet and I was on M1 with only a single fail, so including just one of us (Grace) plus me limits that risk. Missions 2 and 3 share the core {Alice, Charlie, Diana, Henry}, with M2 clean and M3 failing, so I’m benching Charlie, Diana, and Henry entirely this round to avoid repeating that contaminated block. Alice was on both M2 (success) and M3 (single fail) and is widely seen as a reasonable anchor, so I keep her. Bob and Eve are completely fresh to missions so far and are broadly trusted from discussion, giving us two uncontaminated slots. This team—Alice, Bob, Eve, Grace, and myself—maximizes new information while minimizing overlap with proven fail patterns, and keeps the highest-suspect players off the board for this critical mission.

discussion.content: Given M2 was clean but the same core team failed M3, I really want to bench Charlie/Diana/Henry this round and build around me with fresh blood like Bob and Eve plus whichever of Grace/Frank/Iris people feel most comfortable with.

I like building around you, but I’d rather avoid reusing too many people from the M1 fail and M3 fail at once—something like Alice + Bob + two of {Grace, Frank, Iris} and then just one of {Charlie, Henry} feels a lot safer than auto-adding Eve here.

From my perspective M2 proves at least two of {Alice, Diana, Henry} aren’t auto-clear, so I’d like a team like Alice + Bob + one of {Grace/Frank/Iris} + me, and leave both Diana and Henry off this mission to narrow things down.

I’m fine sitting this one out, but I really don’t want to see both Charlie and Henry together again—something like Alice + Bob + Eve plus two from {Grace, Frank, Iris} feels like a cleaner way to test new combos.

I like the idea of centering this on Alice/Bob/Eve and then adding just one of {Grace, Frank, Iris} plus either Charlie or Henry, so we’re not stacking too many players from the same failed missions. That gives us a cleaner read on which pool is actually contaminated if this goes wrong.

I’d really like to keep both Charlie and Henry off after that M3 flip, so something like Alice + Bob + Eve plus one of {Grace/Iris} and one of {Frank/Grace/Iris} feels like a good mix of new info without reusing the same risky core. If people are still wary of M1, I’m fine rotating me with Grace/Iris there, but I do think double-benching Diana/Henry is the priority.
I’m most comfortable with an Alice/Bob/Eve core, and I’d add myself plus just one of {Charlie, Henry}, keeping both Diana and the M1 pair Frank/Iris off this one to minimize the obvious risk pools.
Given M2/M3, I’m pretty sure the leak is in {Alice, Charlie, Diana}, so I’d rather sit out and see a team like Bob + Eve + two of {Grace, Frank, Iris} plus just one from {Alice/Charlie/Diana}.

I really want to avoid stacking both the M1 and M3 risk pools, so I’d like a team of Alice + Bob + Eve plus one of {Grace/Frank} and me, with Charlie, Diana, and Henry all benched this round. That gives us a mostly fresh look while only dipping lightly into each suspicious group.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I tunneled too hard on the wrong people after Mission 1, letting that early fail overly shape my reads and making it easier for evil to blend in on later missions. I did reasonably well at staying flexible after Mission 2’s success, but I needed to push harder for smaller, more controlled teams and to question the repeat of the Mission 2 lineup on Mission 3 instead of accepting it too comfortably.

player_observations.Bob: Played very cautiously and avoided drawing attention, which in hindsight fits Merlin—he nudged teams subtly without over-arguing, making his reads seem like reasonable ‘gut’ rather than inside info.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as consistently straightforward and logic-driven, especially around Missions 2 and 3, which made him feel reliably good even though I didn’t fully lock that in during the game.
player_observations.Diana: Handled suspicion well and leaned into a calm, reasonable tone, which helped her sell the Mission 3 team as safe and made her look like a stabilizing good player rather than Morgana.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed relatively low-key but picked good moments to support narratives that favored evil, rarely taking the spotlight yet helping steer opinions just enough to keep bad teams viable.
player_observations.Frank: Managed to slip under the radar after Mission 1’s fail, not drawing sustained heat despite being on that first mission and later blending in with a fairly neutral, non-confrontational presence.
player_observations.Grace: Felt genuinely good-leaning most of the time, especially early, and seemed to base decisions on table talk and mission history rather than wild accusations, though that didn’t translate into enough effective resistance to bad teams.
player_observations.Henry: Came off as earnest and somewhat reactive—he responded more to others’ arguments than driving his own strong agenda, which made him look like a typical confused good but also made it hard to follow his reads.
player_observations.Iris: Showed moments of strong conviction that didn’t always match my own reads, which in hindsight makes sense as Percival trying to protect Merlin; her leadership on Mission 4 looked confident enough that I gave it too much benefit of the doubt.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly identified all three evil players early from the mission outcomes and team compositions, but I failed to communicate that information subtly enough for my teammates to reliably trust my reads. In future games, I should better balance pushing for specific teams with leaving room for others to reach those conclusions organically, so I don’t draw unnecessary assassin attention or cause town to doubt me.

player_observations.Alice: Alice played cautiously and accepted being on multiple critical teams, which made her look slightly suspicious early despite being good. She seemed willing to go along with consensus rather than forcefully pushing her own solves.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie appeared logical and consistent, reusing a previously successful team on Mission 3, which was reasonable from a good perspective. However, he may have trusted the wrong players a bit too readily, making him vulnerable to manipulation by evil.
player_observations.Diana: Diana (Morgana) blended in well by anchoring herself to prior successful team structures and not overreaching with obvious evil behavior. Her calm participation on both a success and a fail helped maintain plausible deniability.
player_observations.Eve: Eve (Assassin) kept a relatively low profile during missions, avoiding drawing suspicion directly onto herself. Her endgame positioning suggests she paid close attention to who was leading discussions and likely used that to make the assassination decision.
player_observations.Frank: Frank (Mordred) stayed out of the spotlight on missions after the first fail, which helped him avoid becoming a focal point of accusations. His early participation on a failed team without becoming a lasting suspect shows he managed his threat level well.
player_observations.Grace: Grace as good seemed willing to take early mission risks, including going on the failed first mission without over-defending herself afterward. Her playstyle leaned more reactive than proactive, responding to others’ reads rather than driving the table.
player_observations.Henry: Henry played in a straightforward, good-leaning way, supporting teams that seemed logically consistent with prior results. However, he did not strongly challenge the inclusion of suspicious players on repeated mission compositions, which evil could exploit.
player_observations.Iris: Iris (Percival) showed some effort to interpret Merlin/Morgana signals but did not consistently press or protect the right information through team votes. Her choices on the final mission team, which included both confirmed and suspected players, suggest some uncertainty in reading the power roles.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I anchored too much on early mission results without re-evaluating once new information came in, which likely let Diana and Frank stay under-defended suspicion-wise while evil coordinated around them. I did reasonably well supporting broadly good-leaning teams early, but I should have pushed harder to lock in consistent trusted cores and question the sudden flip on the Mission 2 team after its success.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very steady, low-drama good game; tended to back logically consistent teams but may have been a bit too trusting of players who passed early missions.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, seemed to steer subtly rather than forcefully, which kept him relatively hidden but may have made it harder for good to consolidate around the right reads late.
player_observations.Diana: Very effective as Morgana, using the clean Mission 2 result to build trust and then flipping on Mission 3 at a key moment, creating just enough doubt without being overly aggressive.
player_observations.Eve: Kept a low profile as Assassin and avoided drawing attention; blended in as a "middle of the pack" voice, which made the eventual evil coordination feel less obvious.
player_observations.Frank: Slipped in an early fail on Mission 1 and then stayed comfortably in the background, letting others carry most of the table talk while benefiting from the lingering ambiguity.
player_observations.Grace: Came off as genuinely good and straightforward, especially after Mission 1, but seemed to lack enough conviction to strongly redirect suspicion away from the wrong targets.
player_observations.Henry: Played like a solid, reasonable good player—supporting sensible teams and rarely overreacting—which unfortunately made it easier for evil to hide behind his apparent reliability.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, appeared to be actively trying to read Merlin/Morgana signals, but the resulting caution led to at least one critical team choice that still included evil despite good information in play.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated effectively with the rest of the evil team, especially by keeping Mission 2 clean and then pushing the same team on Mission 3 to build trust before flipping it, which helped create confusion around who the real threats were. I could have done a better job subtly shading Bob and protecting Frank and Eve from suspicion earlier, as Merlin and Assassin alignment was a bit clearer than ideal by the endgame.

player_observations.Alice: Alice was willing to go on multiple critical teams and seemed comfortable trusting early mission structures, which made her look reliably good but also somewhat influenceable by stronger table voices.
player_observations.Bob: Bob played a careful Merlin, generally avoiding overt pushes but clearly nudging teams toward more good-heavy compositions, though at times his caution made his reads less impactful than they could have been.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie appeared to prefer logical, consistency-based reasoning and was willing to reuse team templates once they had passed, which made him look stable but also a bit predictable in team selections.
player_observations.Eve: Eve blended in well as evil by not over-controlling discussion and letting others drive team logic, contributing just enough to appear cooperative while preserving flexibility for the final assassination.
player_observations.Frank: Frank played a low-key Mordred, staying out of the direct spotlight and avoiding sharp accusations, which helped him remain off Merlin’s top suspicion list and made him a relatively safe include on early teams.
player_observations.Grace: Grace showed a tendency to take early mission results at face value and appeared to trust social tone and confidence, which made her more persuadable when strong personalities framed the narrative.
player_observations.Henry: Henry seemed cautious and somewhat reactive, often following the emerging consensus on team composition rather than pushing his own agenda, which kept him looking good but limited his influence over the table.
player_observations.Iris: Iris, as Percival, clearly tried to track Merlin through vote patterns and subtle guidance, but her reads on the Merlin/Morgana pair were not fully locked in, which led to some hesitation in late-game trust decisions.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively low-profile while letting other evil roles (especially Diana and Frank) take on more visible risk, which helped keep suspicion off me going into the later missions and preserved my assassination threat. I could improve by being more proactive in shaping table narratives and pushing specific suspicions earlier, so that if the game had gone to an assassination decision, I’d have had clearer, more socially justified targets.

player_observations.Alice: Played in a straightforward, logic-driven way that made her look consistently villager-like, but she didn’t push hard enough to reframe suspicions when evil narratives gained traction.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, he was cautious rather than loud, nudging team compositions instead of hard-clearing or hard-accusing, which made him harder to nail down as a power role but also less influential on the mission outcomes.
player_observations.Charlie: Showed a balanced, cooperative style—asked the right questions and seemed to care about team structure—but didn’t leave very strong signature ‘good’ footprints, which made him blend into the middle of the pack.
player_observations.Diana: As Morgana, she leaned into looking like a strong, info-driven good player, which helped create ambiguity for Percival and gave evil a credible voice when missions were being debated.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, he was comfortable taking early risk (like going on the first mission) while not overtalking, which kept his alignment obscured and let others carry most of the social weight.
player_observations.Grace: Her participation on the first failed mission made her a convenient suspicion sink; after that, she seemed somewhat reactive, defending herself more than driving new lines of inquiry.
player_observations.Henry: Played a solid but somewhat understated good game, often following the emerging consensus rather than forcefully challenging team proposals, which reduced his impact on steering critical mission choices.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, she clearly tried to track Merlin vs. Morgana but didn’t fully translate that into aggressive team curation; her leadership on Mission 4 showed some trust decisions that ultimately benefited evil.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I blended in reasonably well as Mordred on the early missions, helping create just enough uncertainty around who was evil without drawing heavy suspicion onto myself. I could have coordinated more explicitly (through voting patterns and table talk) with Diana and Eve to shape a clearer narrative that framed specific good players, especially around the Mission 3 and 4 team selections.

player_observations.Alice: Played straightforwardly and seemed to trust early mission structures, which made her look generally towny but also a bit influenceable in team selection dynamics.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, he was cautious rather than aggressively steering, which kept him alive but also allowed evil more room to maneuver on critical missions.
player_observations.Charlie: Approached team choices logically and appeared to rely heavily on mission outcomes and voting history, which made his reasoning transparent and relatively easy to anticipate.
player_observations.Diana: Did a strong job as Morgana, projecting a confident good persona and helping create ambiguity around Merlin’s identity through consistent, reasoned commentary.
player_observations.Eve: Played a low-to-mid profile assassin game, not overreaching, which helped preserve flexibility for the endgame shot while still subtly amplifying doubts seeded by other evil players.
player_observations.Grace: Came off as earnest and fairly trusting, which made her an appealing inclusion on teams and a useful barometer of how the more cautious good players were leaning.
player_observations.Henry: Tended to be methodical and a bit conservative in team trust, focusing on previous mission results, which made him slow to fully pivot even when new information suggested alternative narratives.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, strongly engaged in reading Merlin signals and tried to guide team compositions accordingly, but the presence of Morgana clearly pulled her into some key misreads that helped evil succeed.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I trusted the wrong people early, especially after Mission 1, and didn’t push hard enough to clear my name or interrogate why that team failed. I should have focused more on cross-checking team patterns around Diana and Eve, and on reading Merlin signals from Bob instead of treating everyone’s claims and proposals at face value.

player_observations.Alice: Played very straightforwardly and looked consistently good; being on multiple mixed teams without over-defending herself made it harder to find the real evil players around her.
player_observations.Bob: Was cautious and low-key, which fits as Merlin, but the subtlety of his preferences and suspicions made it easy to miss his signals without actively tracking them.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as very reasonable and cooperative, which helped him seem reliably good and made his overlapping teams a useful but underutilized data point.
player_observations.Diana: Blended in well as a core, trustworthy-looking player and repeatedly ended up on critical teams, using that central position to slip a fail into Mission 3 without drawing big blowback.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed relatively under the radar while ending up on the final failing mission, capitalizing on others’ perceived trust networks instead of loudly steering the table herself.
player_observations.Frank: Got early trust from being on the first mission with only one fail and didn’t attract enough follow-up suspicion, which let him fade into the background as an unexamined variable.
player_observations.Henry: Felt like a generally solid, good-leaning voice whose presence on the mixed Mission 2/3 teams complicated reads but didn’t make him stand out as strongly suspicious.
player_observations.Iris: Acted like a central information-holding role, often trying to influence team comps; her trust choices (especially on the last mission) were pivotal but tough to decode from the outside.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed fairly consistent in supporting mission 2’s correct team, which helped confirm some good players, but I didn’t push hard enough to lock in that same core for mission 3. I also should have been more suspicious of Diana after the mission 3 fail and advocated more strongly against the large, mixed mission 4 team that gave evil too much cover.

player_observations.Alice: Appeared generally trustworthy and kept getting picked, which helped good early but also made it easier for evil to hide among familiar names on later missions.
player_observations.Bob: Played Merlin cautiously, not oversteering team choices, which made him look reasonably neutral but may have limited how much he could subtly correct bad team proposals.
player_observations.Charlie: Gravitated toward the successful mission 2 team, which was good, but didn’t fully capitalize on that information to resist repeating or expanding into more suspicious lineups later.
player_observations.Diana: Blended very well as evil by sticking close to previously successful team compositions and only introducing a single fail at a time to avoid drawing attention.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed in the background of team selection yet ended up on the critical failing mission 4, suggesting a low-profile, opportunistic evil style.
player_observations.Frank: Got early access to mission 1, used the single fail to sow doubt without overexposing, and then stayed out of the spotlight afterward, which made him hard to pin down.
player_observations.Grace: Her inclusion on the failed first mission made her look suspicious early, and she didn’t have many later chances to clearly prove her loyalty.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, she seemed genuinely uncertain between Merlin and Morgana and allowed Diana to stay highly trusted, which was pivotal in giving evil repeated mission access.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly focused on the Merlin/Morgana pair, but I misread the signals and didn’t protect Merlin effectively, especially given how late my clarity came on Bob versus Diana. I also failed to push harder against the risky team on Mission 4, where I should have leveraged my information role to argue more forcefully for excluding at least one suspected evil player.

player_observations.Alice: You consistently looked clean and played in a straightforward, transparent way, which made you an anchor for good teams but also a relatively easy player for evil to hide around. Your willingness to repeat mostly similar teams made it harder to break out of the frame evil had set.
player_observations.Bob: You played a very subtle Merlin, often choosing not to hard-push your reads, which kept you alive but made it harder for me as Percival to distinguish you clearly from Morgana. Your low-key style worked well for survival, but it left your soft pushes a bit too ambiguous in the late game.
player_observations.Charlie: You played very cautiously, rarely making bold accusations, which helped you seem reliably good but didn’t generate much new information. Your alignment felt trustworthy, but you could have challenged team comps more aggressively, especially after the first fail.
player_observations.Diana: You were an effective Morgana, projecting just enough insight to plausibly be Merlin without over-claiming, which really pulled my attention away from Bob. Your steady presence on Missions 2 and 3 made you look like a core-good player and helped evil control the narrative.
player_observations.Eve: You stayed relatively under the radar socially and let others drive the team discussions, which is strong assassin play because it preserved flexibility for the final kill. Your decisions around mission teams avoided drawing attention, making it difficult to pin you as evil until it was too late.
player_observations.Frank: You took advantage of the early failing Mission 1 to muddy reads without over-explaining, which kept suspicion broadly distributed instead of focusing tightly on you. Your low-profile approach as Mordred blended well with the table and made you a persistent background threat.
player_observations.Grace: You played like a straightforward good player, trusting early teams and not overcomplicating your logic, which made you feel honest but also somewhat influenceable. When missions started failing, you adapted, but you could have been more vocal about pushing safer, smaller cores.
player_observations.Henry: You approached the game logically and tried to lean on mission results more than social reads, which is solid, but you sometimes gave too much benefit of the doubt to repeated team structures. Your generally calm demeanor helped you look good, but you might improve by more sharply questioning players who sat on multiple failing missions.
